addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord Highe Treasurer of England.

section.hand:
27 March
1591
M
r
Bodley.
Em
p
a
bassador
Cont Moryce
Hoh
e
lo
Mons
r
Bouz
e
vall

page.lettertext:
fol.272r
May it please yo
r
good L. The Empero
rs
Am-
bassado
r
hath had his Audience of
e
states,
who are
nowe come together in competent number. His
demaunde was no other, then I have signified heere-
tofore, That his felowe Commissioners might have
a Pasport of
e states, to come safely to the Hage.
Howbeit his speeches were quicke in taxing
e assem-
blie, for suffering those of
Brussels,
and himself in
this place, to attend so long w
t
out an answear.
There was nothing in writing delivered by him, nor
yet any thing required. For they are doubtfull
what to doe, in regard of
e vulgar people, among
whome it is thought,
at
e copies spredde abroade
of suche Propositions, will produce no good effectes.
Nevertheles there are some men sette a worke about
framing an answear: w
ch
will be negative all-
together, and yet contrived in suche sort, as both
it may contene
e reasons of their refusall, to
hearcken to those Ambassado
rs
and likewise their
desire, to come to a Pacification. Moreover, as
I suppose, they will resolve to send their answear,
not onely to
e Emperor but to divers Princes of
e Empire, and also publishe it in print.
They are wholy buisied heere, about making pro-
vision to goe into
e feelde: and I thinke they
will be ready w
t
in a moneth at
e farthest.
Howbeit it is not yet notified, w
at
e Provinces
will contribut. If her
Ma
tie
holde her
purpose, to persaude w
t
e states, to imploie their
forces this sommer in
e warres of
France,
and to
reserve no more at home, then for defence of their townes,
fol.272v
it will be needefull, in my opinion to attempt it
out of hand, and
at
e
Kinge
doe concurre and,
that very earnestly, in
e self same petition.
I have imparted it at large unto M
r
Buzenval,
who embraced it presently, w
t
a very good liking
but perceaving after, as I doe conjecture, that
it would not be pleasing to Count Maurice, to w h ome
he would not but be pleasing, I doe finde him a
litle shrinking, and alleaging against it, That
e King may receave as great
a
benefit, by the
exploites of these contreis, as by
e use of those
men,
at they may spare him. But his arguments
are so feeble, as they rather seeme to be sought of
sette purpose, then presented unto him, upon good
discourse of reason. I should thinke it very
requisit, in respect of his backwardnes, that some
letter of charge from
e Kinge, or of advise from
Mons
r
de Nocle
, were sent unto him.
It is commonly spoken heere, that
e mariage be-
tween Count Hohenloo and
e
Countesse of Buren
Count Maurices sister, shal be shortly solemnised.
And many men imagine, it will occasion great
dissention between
e two Countes. For
e Coun-
tesse complaineth,
at her brother doth oppresse
her in sundrie great causes, whiche Count Ho-
henloo will not tolerat, if he were maried to
the Countesse, as he openly professeth. Moreo-
ver for these three or fower yeres,
e counte-
nance and cariage of Count Maurice towardes
him, hath rather bin unloving, and disdainfull,
and framed to depresse him, then respective to
his qualitie, to his merites towardes his father, and
fol.273r
his former good services. Wherat Count Hohenloo
hath greatly grieved for a long time together: and
nowe, as it seemeth, by report of those speeches,
w
ch
he uttereth to divers, he will take more know-
ledge of suche usage. It is surmised
at he hath
secret frindes in this state,
at are in good credit,
and encourage him to this course. I can not
yet conceave,
at this division between them, will
growe to
at degree, as to disturbe
e proceedinges
of
e affaires of
e state: but I am thorowly
persuaded, it may turne her Ma
tie
in time to spe-
ciall good service, in many of her causes.
I have bin earnest this day w
t
e Assemblie of the
states, about some order to be taken, for
e amen-
ding of their Placcart of Commerce w
t
Spaine,
to
e effect of those notes, w
ch
I receaved from her Ma
tie
and proposed unto them in Oc
t
last: whereto by
reason of their recesse, and no meeting till nowe,
they could make me no answear. I have
also exhibited her Ma
ties
l
re
in
e favor of my
L.
Willughby
: and an other lately sent hither, for
e Marchants of
Middlebourgh:
bothe w
ch
causes
I have solicited, w
t
all convenient instance.
Assoone as I have their answear (for they require
to thinke upon it) I will send it yo
r
L.
It is greatly feared by many men heere, that
the Spaniarde will watche the returne of their
shippes out of
Italy,
w
ch
are thought to be there to
e
nomber of 300 and imploye them in his service
intended this sommer.
Thus I take my
humble. From
e Hage. Marche 27 1592
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
We have an ad-
vertisment heere, w
ch
we take to be assured,
that
e
D. of Parma
is nowe at
S
t
Omar
, and is to goe very
shortly to
e Spawe.
